Award.AwardTitle: IEEE Nano Materials & Devices Conference - NMDC-2018 To Be Held In Portland OR, October 14-17, 2018.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project will provide support to young student and scientist participation, in a conference to be held in the Embassy Suites Downtown, Portland OR, USA, during October 14-17, 2018. The "13th IEEE Nano Materials & Devices Conference (NMDC 2018)" will focus on the development of nanomaterials and nanodevices for space, electronic, magnetic, sensor, photonic systems and biomedical applications. The Symposium will host world-renowned scientists in academia and national labs, industry workers, entrepreneurs, and funding agency leaders in the general area of nanotechnology. Student Fellowships will support domestic student presenters to attend the meeting. The program provides the opportunity for scientific exchanges and discussions. There will be a vigorous exchange of new ideas on materials and devices that will benefit enormously students and young scholars in their pursuit of high-quality research. There will be conference proceedings available to the public through the archival IEEE Xplore. Selected papers will also be invited for publication in the IEEE Transactions on Nanotechnology, the IEEE Nanotechnology Magazine and possibly other journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 IEEE Nano Materials & Devices Conference (NMDC), sponsored by the IEEE Nanotechnology Council (NTC), was held on October 14th to 17th in Portland, Oregon. This annual conference rotates between Europe, Asia and North America, and brings together researchers, educators, and students working on the development of nanomaterials and nanodevices for space, electronic, magnetic, sensor, photonic systems and biomedical applications.  It provides a rich and integrative environment for young scientists that have a unique opportunity to engage and establish networks with well-established professionals within their specific fields of nanotechnology. The conference is not just an opportunity to showcase creative research, it is place for young scientists to gain feedback about their work and form collaborative opportunities to advance their science. To support the endeavors of these young students and scientists, $10,000 was granted by the NSF for Student Fellowships to support the attendance of domestic student presenters. The financial support was used primarily to offset the costs of hotel accommodation but also to assist with student registration costs.

 

A total of 47 students attended the conference of 172 total, including 115 “university” and 57 “other.” Conference details can be found on the conference website at: www.ieeenmdc.org/nmdc-2018/

 

Air travel costs from various parts of the country vary greatly and are further complicated by seat availabilities, date of booking, baggage costs, etc., so accommodation costs were identified as a more equitable target for support. Attendance for the complete conference was regarded as essential to the full experience and hotel expenses were identified as being the greatest impediment to students attending the full conference rather than just coming for the single day of their own presentations. There was a call for applications and deadline posted on the conference website and distributed by the NTC’s Newsletter and various social media. All student applications received by the deadline were fully funded, i.e. 14 students received 100% of their hotel room costs, including taxes, for 3 or 4 nights as requested, sharing 2/suite, or 50% for sole occupancy. All these also received a 33% partial reimbursement of their conference fees. Three local students received 50% conference fee reimbursements to permit full attendance rather than only one day. And finally there was enough remaining to provide a smaller grant to a marginally late applicant, making 18 student grants in all.

 

The 18 student grantees co-authored and presented a total of 24 papers and won the awards for Best Paper and runner-up, neither being limited to student papers.

 

The student papers have been disseminated in the conference proceedings to all the conference attendees and will appear soon in the official proceedings published on-line in IEEE Xplore.

 

The nanotechnology field is inherently multi-disciplinary and the technical sessions covered the fields of preparation, properties (electrical, optical, thermal, mechanical, magnetic, photonic) and applications of nanomaterials and nanodevices (energy, nanoelectronics, sensors, biomedical,) including experimental and simulation studies, focused on nanoparticles and composites, CNTs and 2D materials, etc. The academic disciplines represented include physics, chemistry, electrical and mechanical engineering, materials science and engineering, biology, and more. In addition to the traditional technical sessions, there was one and an evening panel session on nanotechnology education, and two student focused evening workshops on early career skills and the “Art of Negotiation.”

 

The conference experience can be exceptionally motivational to students, and especially to a first-time student presenter. In addition to the specific knowledge that a young researcher gains in his/her own research field, the exposure to researchers in the student’s research area but from different disciplines broadens the student’s understanding of the field. Although the data is incomplete, the organizers are sure that at least some of the NSF awardees would not have been able to attend the whole conference without the NSF support, rather than just for the day of their presentation, (in addition to the three local students.)
